THE BACKGROUND OF THE DREAM
In the early 20*3, as radio program broadcasting began to become a factor on
the American scene, many educational agencies and institutions entered the
field and established broadcasting stations of their own* The process is
fairly well described in Whitens "American Radio" part of the University of
Chicago Freedom of the Press Report under a chapter headed "The Light that
Failed"o This report pointed out that nearly 200 institutions had at one
time achieved broadcast licenses but that by the early 1930*s the number had
diminished to under 1*0 institutionso Licensees initially had included boards
of education, colleges, universities, etc®
Actually several factors leading to this disappointing attrition were at work*
1® Many of the licensees were in fact not broadcasting enterprises at
all, but rather the licensed experimental activity of a physics de¬
partment or an electrical engineering laboratory®
2* When the actual day-by-day program realities began to impinge on
these stations—for both philosophical and fiscal reasons—they
ceased to be®
3. Many educators failed to see the tremendous potential in radio broad¬
casting and measured the future opportunities against the-then-
existent performance standards of commercial stations whose program
fare was by and large cheap and distasteful to them®
None of the "great" universities such as Yale, Harvard, Columbia, the Uni¬
versity of Chicago, etc® ever operated stations of their own. Significantly
most of the survivors of the 30 *s were Land-Grant College institutions where
the chartered obligation of the school was to serve "all of the citizens of
the state, not those on the campus alone”. Hence, the concept of wide-audience
service as opposed to the "cloistered hall” concept of the normal liberal arts
institutions made such a medium as radio more understandable as a device for
a Land-Grant college to use®
The hopes were high in the early days and as one individual put it, "educators
set up stations expecting the thirsty thousands to come and drink from the
fountain of learningj however, while the waters flowed the citizens were drink¬
ing from other sources, wooed by the strains of music preceding plugs for
toothpaste and other items of commerce”®
The NAEB and other organizations in an early day developed an elaborate plan
of national organization for educational broadcasting with a pattern of
foundation financing which has elements of similarity to the present education¬
al television development® Unhappily, much of the money in the 20*s and 30's
went into an unrewarding kind of research. A great deal of time and monqy
were spent on "evaluating educational programs" when obviously the crying need
was to create and produce educational programs of some merit and quantity,
according to the best current judgments available—and then to really display
them. It was as if the Metropolitan Opera in its initial New York performance
had put up a tent, pared the budget for "II Trovatore”, eliminated half the
cast and all the sets, used a five-piece "combo** instead of the full orchestra,
